title: Grade 11 - Agriculture and Sustainable Food Systems 20 (2022)
subject: Practical and Applied Arts

document.title: Grade 11 - Agriculture and Sustainable Food Systems 20 (2022)

B36145EF1ABF42F49FB4640A4F893806.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

FBFDBF18A8884D80A0406B8BD917D20F.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

14EBF4A0A8C449AEB0146AF0320460D9.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

2C1F30A2CCDB4103BECD44FF3E8875EE.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals

11C4060240604674B985EB2C2E4042EA.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

DED9662023EA4B36B00378D072D8B27B.description: Relate personal work placement experience to personal and career goals.

B4227C0D9EB144EB8694C8C3FA546F37.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

1FA351F386734BF5A10A8EED85E68766.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

B57FD8F5633B464CB166FAE8A2D3A1E1.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

9A8213DBB24D45E6B3E62CAFF17A64EE.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

F3F81CA21BEE490880FF5CDD60F63DA3.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

237EB0BBFCC349E9AFF302A477A3E8F8.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

518FA15769E74A2B967E1C71607A4684.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

8C6C63F8E44340B899AC5A0E6A15FA45.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours?,Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?,  Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

53DE00D6832A44B0B1CD99782A68D652.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

F6878F1D7A094287ADBAD309D67AACE6.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

ED2FBBE62B24487394853C2ECE7541B9.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

7C7494BC1E1B4F458D1ACDF0A3813D93.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

04DFD1B741E7482484EB560A3D96A47F.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

45DF1458C6FF4FCBA342BAF6254F1DC7.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

E11FBD0034B740D5B965D58D1B71AF8E.description: Identify emerging career opportunities related to agriculture and climate change.

2C2E7A526F6B4DD884F7862609824D29.description: Contemplate who should be responsible for increased costs of agricultural production predicted to accompany climate change.

A7CAADD5E7704D07A130348379AAF516.description: Describe current research and actions undertaken by agricultural producers to adapt to climate change.

BE0B689DC72747B1BBFF69C583A5452E.description: Explore the impact of climate change in Canada and a select developing country, including: potential changes to types of crops that can be grown: changes in production practices that will be required; and, the severity of impact on the domestic food system.

9A785FEDE7EC4F298CC422DA63560C56.description: Identify what countries are likely to be most significantly affected by climate change.

DE16D1DE05E349DC902B42B8610151FD.description: Predict the impact on developing countries if food staples can no longer be grown.

C29400E7E6CD4F9C84E679E66F01F0A1.description: Research predicted impacts of climate change on local, provincial, national and international food systems.

C9AB839BC3014C27B77E9D83FDE6D7DB.description: Compare effects of natural disasters on food security in accessible and remote locations

EBF335AA3A744A33AD9613076B1C4A8A.description: Interpret comparative data regarding major weather events in Canada in previous 5 years and previous 100 years.

F5460E9661DB453D974EC2D83EA21785.description: Identify changing patterns of animal migration over the past decade and quarter century.

C724F99333564671849CF2DDF946228A.description: Investigate models predicting the impact of climate change on food security and agricultural production.

FAEEEA6568004D18B2057BA47BCBE527.description: Climate Change, Agriculture and Food Security (Core)

488087DE5807468BB5D6F90D3FA516EB.description: Reflect on challenges and successes experienced in planning, planting and maintaining an indoor garden.

A18E89FBD0D24402AB22AB7E62A00650.description: Implement a plan for, and monitor progress of, an indoor garden.

9A1B519EBC314F0DAC29E0E6E92F5A67.description: Design a plan for an indoor garden, including location, required materials and associated costs.

9126A009B8AE442ABD6F43A7506DB6A4.description: Assess the availability of, and costs associated with, typical indoor garden requirements.

5A92AA8784104AE8AD24EA08A1B76BF3.description: Research typical requirements (e.g., lighting, water, equipment, tools, supplies) for an indoor garden.

85E4EBB80B43424E827F4DD3282A115D.description: Differentiate between edible plants that are conducive for growing indoors to others that are difficult to grow indoors (e.g., vegetables and leafy greens vs. fruit-bearing and vining plants).

811C46558AC5409DBE6A7558BCCEB34D.description: Examine tips for growing and maintaining a thriving indoor garden.

ACDE7E80B76345268C13DB12B0728661.description: Discuss the benefits of an indoor garden such as year-round availability to fresh produce, protection from weather elements, air purification; and emotional therapy.

35841588EB794BE28123FFD8B30B519C.description: Identify methods for gardening and pest management used in the local community and surrounding area.

610080AD63494DC6A500DDAC1B6D1D42.description: Research current methods (e.g., cultural, natural, chemical, biological) for sustainable weed and pest control and management.

7F5D4310CAB348D8B80534F4A1F959A8.description: Discuss the importance of weed and pest control and management.

A434834CA76A402EB6ABC18C58718215.description: Assess factors (e.g., available space, types of plants desired, lifestyle) that influence the selection of gardening methods.

A9F59C787DFE47DD835AA833642391BB.description: Compare the advantages and disadvantages of several gardening methods.

E74752FCF278479D987899543D4B6EB2.description: Examine various non-traditional gardening methods such as: aquaponics; Back to Eden; container; core; edible landscaping; hanging; hydroponics; lasagna; raised beds; rooftop; square foot; straw bale; upside-down; and, vertical.

97E58C9D7A914B93A2FA6639C664AFA1.description: Propose ways (e.g., giving away seeds, offering community classes, sharing excess produce) to encourage gardening within the community.

9283567C201042A5BCBFFE7943E604FC.description: Discuss gardening as a potential means of supporting food security for individuals, families and communities.

AA8F9B809A6D4F82BC13836F94ED9960.description: Examine gardening practices that support food security.

9B68F5993EF44C2E8C52CC2B6951CB0D.description: Explore food-producing plants (e.g., trees, shrubs, vegetables) that are suitable for growing within the local area and other areas of the province.

0642A2211DD04BB6B2F2FE389BE81193.description: Identify hardiness zones in Saskatchewan and Canada.

9468A8A542654F699EB870BA6802D3CD.description: Define the term hardiness zone as a geographic area with a range of conditions conducive to plants’ growth and survival.

493CAB569DF64463B2FB4B95717EFD84.description: Identify conditions (e.g., climate, drainage, elevation, sunlight) that contribute to plant survival.

EEF9220013DE4CD4B110687E46ACAFE9.description: Research uses (e.g., food, medicine, utility, ceremonial) of traditional plants grown by First Nations peoples in Saskatchewan.

F0B2A5D8DC504FC382F42B2F3A37EFA8.description: Describe the contribution that horticulture can make to food security

AFE505F35A054E4887864787E92638A8.description: Differentiate between edible and ornamental horticulture.

CF99F0CE5312457887364826D5254784.description: Differentiate between horticulture and larger scale agriculture.

61914C1BEF8041D6BCC4020A78FEB065.description: Identify examples of horticulture such as landscaping, gardening and growing crops for food, fiber and fuel.

382092F9F54C4952B6FC35D47DD2DA19.description: Examine the role of horticulture in supporting food security.

6FA8A58D9FD747148CD6C26F0681C458.description: Investigate the role of Saskatchewan’s Water Security Agency in maintaining water safety and security in the province.

4EAD1505F0DC432C9D67A83E546799BC.description: Research historical and contemporary issues associated with livestock production and water stewardship.

9DB75F9C6C5F48E0B5BC79025394E45B.description: Identify issues associated with water management related to food production in Saskatchewan, including: ripple effect-how one action can impact another’s land; impact of individual local decisions on watersheds; water security needs and opportunities; and, intended and unintended consequences of human altered water drainage patterns.

EB3040BCE48D4B45B45C6C81E027F09C.description: Research characteristics (e.g., size, slope, shape, drainage, density, land use/land cover, geology and soils, vegetation) of the local watershed.

CCDD332433874CEC98E905361C127ED6.description: Identify geographic boundaries for Saskatchewan’s major watersheds.

ABC2A364770746B0B5D2D6137F634B60.description: Describe the purpose of a watershed and its relation to agricultural production.

2BB221A765D44443982FF9AA2BF3C268.description: Examine the effectiveness of various methods (e.g., minimum tillage, crop rotation) for maintaining soil health.

9E6D1204D28D4B138FEA05C1817A756D.description: Research current methods for reducing soil erosion (e.g., planting trees, land cover, direct seeding).

E5016AD0EE7C4859A4E36B820DB14092.description: Explain the 4 Rs of nutrient stewardship: right source; right place; right amount; and, right time.

D3AC0372EE624B3788CDDCF22A78E132.description: Discuss the importance of historical and contemporary grain and livestock production practices that conserve water and soil quality.

99894E433594493081F1F8E8F6D68C2E.description: Explore traditional practices used by Indigenous peoples to maintain land and water health.

1CD2A3BDA91D4B7E8279C4DE1CF0096A.description: Discuss the relationship between sustainability and water and soil quality.

66490583C8984BC9B8230D7B6C4284AB.description: Investigate the importance of soil and water stewardship in sustainable agriculture and food systems.

E2C52300C4DD4A4FABCB7E2248B82CCE.description: Hypothesize opportunities for expanding local food sources.

466E441E74EF48669FBD19EC26B08E9A.description: Compare traditional Indigenous food sources to contemporary food sources.

E1781BED2F6A4D4C84D5A777CDBC863E.description: Assess the availability and origin of food produced locally, such as: produce; grains; meat; and, fish

B02D46DDDF3C44A3987B75D04D53D768.description: Investigate influences (e.g., diverse cultures, food trends, health needs) on product availability in Saskatchewan grocery stores

AAF25B5714514BCC849E0F12F5D50D7F.description: Research changes in the types of food products available locally over the past decade and quarter century.

E885CDE5E0204CD78779B84D3B89B858.description: Investigate factors (e.g., consumer demand for healthier food choices, convenience, changing cultural demographics, environmental impact) that contribute to changing food consumption preferences of Saskatchewan residents.

940E53FE4CD041E6B88B590170682DDB.description: Examine the origins of food produced in Saskatchewan.

087DAA47B8054C8891684B77480E5DDA.description: Explore factors (e.g., availability of cultivated farmland, innovations in crop varieties) that have helped to position Saskatchewan as a major global supplier of food.

C27D901FD1B34260B3E35FAC2404BC1F.description: Identify emerging sustainability actions being undertaken voluntarily by Saskatchewan food producers.

9554A6EEE27445ED95FD1913085ABF47.description: Research innovations in sustainable agriculture practices that are attributed to Saskatchewan.

9F6604E8365143DF8255FD9A4B9277C4.description: Describe the relationship between sustainable agriculture and sustainable food systems.

96429FB2219D4510A6928A6B045E283B.description: Examine factors (e.g., religious, social, cultural, ecological and economic) that influence agricultural practices.

BA83A83AF43E4E7E8C424F5A4ED0D466.description: Compare Indigenous approaches to food production within First Nations communities in Saskatchewan pre- and post-contact.

D9746CE8AF4745B7AEC2AFC2208A622E.description: Investigate the importance and application of standards and regulations for export, import and trade in agricultural products within Canadian and international contexts

90320F7A175E47CE99EE5889C1842C51.description: Assess statistics related to Saskatchewan’s exporting and importing of both primary and value-added agricultural products.

C6ADCAA82B03443983FE293F47D45C91.description: Explore the origins and uses of agricultural by-products (e.g., poultry feathers for pillows, canola meal for livestock feed, flax straw and hemp for building materials, straw from cereal grains for bedding for animals or ethanol production).

5A6265D30BAA4549BCE567AE6D328472.description: Identify primary production and value-added agricultural products produced in various regions of Saskatchewan, including the local area.

7CD7B0FC9D124C99B1091E258FA899A4.description: Differentiate between primary production (i.e., raw agricultural products such as cereal grains or vegetables) and value-added agricultural products (e.g., fruits made into pies or jams, meats made into jerky).

BC6001291E62496F86AFBEBE4DF671F2.description: Assess the sustainability of agricultural practices in Saskatchewan.

153AF051863A4C0594D65295298214EF.description: Develop a plan for becoming more food literate.

E6BAA0437D734DC7B56D6A69AE461E1E.description: Appraise personal food literacy skills and understanding.

3F0B463024504BDC93E777170C9F6DC6.description: Debate the merits of shopping for local and Canadian food.

880AF55264894880BAA71094A063E286.description: Assess the importance of food traceability.

967D89267FB2450C8CB42EDFA62BBF48.description: Identify food traceability requirements and methods used in Canada.

5FA6B7FBB84B44FA8F6315CAF04FA8CA.description: Compare Canada’s reliance on imported versus domestic foods.

8708A4CC0C3440408B618771C67BA3E1.description: Articulate the limitations of using only food miles/kilometers as the measure for deciding what is a good food choice.

F2C64B68C8144FB5A059737192F4F7A7.description: Identify the origin of an imported food item (e.g., fresh fruit, spice, coffee), the food miles/kilometers associated with that item and potential modes of transportation used to get it to its destination.

0F982C733C714BD88D8F9A2982C33246.description: Define the concept of food miles/food kilometers.

878DCDC51E6A47E5AF1198B632EC08D8.description: Differentiate between information for health and nutritional purposes and information for marketing purposes found on food packaging in Canada

C7E875FB8100480FBC83CB26C2AE09F2.description: Assess personal knowledge of food labelling information.

98A3F7DDFF7A409FA4D78EB409F8D4ED.description: Explain the reasons for food labelling in Canada.

095201B9CD6D4E259B884B18246CC32F.description: Research Canada’s packaged food labeling requirements pertaining to: the product (e.g., list of ingredients; allergens; durable life date; country of origin; name and address of the manufacturer, dealer or importer); product health and safety (e.g., safe storage, handling); product nutritional information (e.g., quantity of fats, proteins, carbohydrates, vitamins and minerals per serving of stated size); and, what is not required in the labelling.

7CF196F4597047EABCB4F88238CB22E0.description: Discuss the relationship between a healthy diet, a nutritional food supply and nutritional well-being, and the health and productivity of Canadians.

6924D2F7E276404D974CBA252F3E15E2.description: Examine the role of Health Canada in establishing policies, regulations and standards related to the safety and nutritional quality of all food sold in Canada.

DAA12812E09440B18A7BDA9DE201B43E.description: Assess the benefits to self and others (e.g., family, community) of being food literate.

37A0725ED21E4BAF83E46800303C216F.description: Examine the importance of food literacy.

50E5812611C34EB2A0D42FF87A0B7E86.description: Reflect on personal actions (e.g., eating and buying local, cooking more, composting) that support local sustainable food systems.

43204559A7B24E11862EBE442A6D7CEA.description: Propose solutions to issues currently challenging the sustainability of food systems.

22B673593E7A446796EAB2BA201101CD.description: Investigate factors that may challenge the sustainability of a food system.

3EBDBA05A6DF460499BD65D5D15DBB20.description: Identify characteristics of a sustainable food system.

E2087B61734F4D4390D394ED5A6C5B61.description: Compare the operation of food systems within different regions of Canada.

F5471C31EDAE4071BE46F5B69C251271.description: Describe the interconnectedness of food systems on a local, provincial, national and global scale.

6E6B9C3292554B52917FAC4BAC8DF455.description: Research the types of activities associated with each stage of the food system, such as: growing field crops, raising livestock or poultry (production); washing, cutting and preserving fruits and vegetables; grinding nuts into nut butter; cutting and packing meat; creating baked goods (processing); transporting and distributing food products; and, serving consumers via grocery stores, corner convenience stores, vending machines, and restaurants

B594F81A622B4EACBB7F155D30BDE573.description: Identify the four stages (i.e., production, processing, distribution, consumption) of a food system.

6C24AB89F78B4410B24153173594CC77.description: Explain the concept of a food system.

0B994252FB7B42D091267EF2B1D565B7.description: Evaluate the role played in facilitating and maintaining food sovereignty by individuals and entities such as: food growers; food providers (e.g., grocery stores, local farmers’ markets, restaurants); governments; nutritionists; and, consumers.

65C508B009AA4D7DAE971A068ACC7BF5.description: Identify challenges and opportunities faced by newcomers and First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples and communities in achieving food sovereignty.

FFD379ED62AD4A35891B890D483A8780.description: Examine benefits of food sovereignty such as: local economic development; preserving traditional lifestyles; sustainability of livelihoods; availability of fresh produce and other food in local grocery stores and restaurants; and, increased capacity for supplying and accessing food locally.

A03E85AB508B4461BFD59D8B59A82820.description: Assess the relationship between food sovereignty and food security.

F5C3250859CA4A2696F50E8239637090.description: Explore the importance of food sovereignty.

DF24F95B13164CACA83A5546B2ABD19C.description: Identify approaches for improving food security in the local community or region.

04EA30EE0E6847C3AD876A0DBDBCD968.description: Discuss the roles that individuals, organizations and local, provincial, First Nations and federal governments can play in alleviating food insecurity.

3FE739342D694460ACF0541C911E2EB3.description: Reflect on personal and collective responsibility for addressing local and global food security.

E1F10F6A04404C0B9BFDAAF0934996C5.description: Identify organizations (e.g., World Vision, Red Cross) and their responses to global food insecurity.

19FA0F73E0CF45E2ADB87C9128F54016.description: Investigate contemporary and historical examples of food used as a weapon in conflict.

1D25B7F0589241FCB01487008C5E9983.description: Compare the current state of food insecurity in Canada to the global state of food insecurity.

423469BEB168466CB60E490CAFC13486.description: Investigate the current global state of food insecurity, including geographic variations and root causes.

E0BA32B052D44FC0A8AEA44403D22C99.description: Research grassroots approaches (e.g., community fridge, food banks, food drives, community gardens) for alleviating food insecurity in Canada.

5A079889741344DC80BEFEBB1744D134.description: Conduct an inquiry into the impact of food insecurity on Canadians, considering factors such as regional differences and vulnerable population groups.

D7E3D056030B480EAB9F078A1A396691.description: Discuss the importance of food security.

F2913100E4304E0C9E7D23DF885753F4.description: Explore solutions to local and global food insecurity.

51436508F87548BBB39C96314BF07FEB.description: Differentiate between chronic and transitory food insecurity.

4CB43B463DAB49388B8BAB2DB6A0716F.description: Research factors (e.g., lack of access to farming lands; conflict, violence and wars; unfair trade rules; natural disasters) that influence food insecurity on a larger scale.

B69151BF1A094F408606743C2FAE1641.description: Examine the impact of factors such as income, employment and culture on food insecurity for individuals, families and communities.

22E02D86D2EC4A749FE665874DD0F39C.description: Examine the role of each of the following in influencing food security: farmers and producers; • processors and manufacturers; retailers; newcomers to Canada First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples and communities; consumers at diverse income levels;  government (municipal, provincial, federal); and,  individuals and groups with environmental stewardship as a priority.

E5DA73FB7A904B39AE633625E87BB914.description: Assess the four pillars of food security in relation to availability, access, utilization/cultural relevance and stability.

FAAAC9DD4B5A4E32AA391A0A80152828.description: Defend food security as a basic human right.

353A22F31F32406C95D88F070F3CB27D.description: Explain the United Nations’ definition of food security.

36C24942DC1C49139BF17AFDE995424B.description: Explore the emotional and physical importance of food, considering factors such as food abundance, food choices and lack of food.

B2A95838E534477A8864DDCB376CF894.description: Investigate the importance of food and food security.

64B6450E3E8E4944A43D09FDF9BE8D24.description: Propose personal and collective actions that might support the Seventh Generation Principle.

0C6F15F51DB3426F92468E3EBC57EDEE.description: Research sustainability and stewardship according to the Seventh Generation Principle.

65112EAF62034AE9808741970D3E23F3.description: Discuss the relationship between sustainability and stewardship.

A1F4EF2F7A2A4BD8996D986B25EEBAB8.description: Reflect on what it means to be a good steward.

B2BDB990CCCA45C1AA13096F83FE0D30.description: Describe the purpose and components of each of the four pillars of sustainability (i.e., social, human, economic, environmental).

ED6D191C52A64172B77D3452D257EA66.description: Examine the relationship between stewardship and sustainability.
